alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for Christmas bonuses
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing Christmas bonuses
title: Expenses and benefits: Christmas bonuses

table.body:
As an employer providing Christmas bonuses to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

This depends on:

* whether you give cash bonuses or goods (gifts) to an employee
* if you give goods to an employee, whether or not they can be resold for cash
* whether the employee is a director, and how much they earn
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance if: 

- you give goods that can't be resold for cash to employees who earn [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the Christmas bonuses you provide aren't [exempt](/christmas-bonus-expenses/whats-exempt "exempt"), you may have to report them to HMRC, and deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on them.

##Cash bonus

Any cash you give to employees as a Christmas bonus counts as earnings, so you'll need to:

* add the value to your employee’s other earnings
* deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

##Goods

If you give goods as Christmas gifts to employees, what you have to report and pay depends on:

* whether or not they can be resold for cash
* whether you give them to company directors or employees who earn [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year

Expense | What to do | What to pay
- | - | -
Goods with no resale value you give to employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, unless these are counted as [trivial benefits](/# "trivial benefits") | Fill in form P11D, section A or M | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit
Goods with no resale value you give to directors, unless these are counted as [trivial benefits](/# "trivial benefits") | Fill in form P11D, section A or M | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit
Goods with cash resale value you give to employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year | Fill in form P9D, section A(2) | Nothing
Goods with cash resale value you give to employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Form P11D, section A | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit
Goods with cash resale value you give to directors | Form P11D, section A | Pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
The amount you need to report depends on the type of bonus you provide.

##Cash bonuses

Use the amount you pay to the employee.

##Goods with no resale value

Use the amount the goods cost you.

##Goods with cash resale value

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year, use the resale value of the goods.

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or directors, use whichever is the higher of:

* the resale value
* the amount the goods cost you
